frontmatter.title: Assignment: Climate change in the zero-dimensional EBM

children.value: Students completing this assignment will gain the following skills and concepts:
Familiarity with the zero-dimensional Energy Balance Model
Understanding of the adjustment toward equilibrium temperature
Introduction to the concept of ice-albedo feedback
Use of numerical timestepping to find the equilibrium temperature
Python programming skills: arrays, loops, and simple graphs
In a local copy of this notebook (on the JupyterHub or your own device)
add your answers in additional cells
. These are meant to be interesting and thought-provoking, but are not required. Extra credit will be given for interesting answers to the bonus problems.
to run your notebook on the UAlbany JupyterHub. Remember to set your kernel to
Remember you can add new cells using the “+” button, and set your cell types to
in your code to explain your method as necessary.
Remember to actually answer the questions.
Written answers in Markdown cells are required
that contains your text, your code, and your figures.
Did the notebook run from start to finish without error and produce the expected output?
If yes, save again and submit your notebook file.
If no, fix the errors and try again.

Problem 2: Albedo feedback in the Energy Balance Model

children.label: Problem 2: Albedo feedback in the Energy Balance Model

children.value: For this exercise, we will introduce a new physical process into our model by
letting the planetary albedo depend on temperature
. The idea is that a warmer planet has less ice and snow at the surface, and thus a lower planetary albedo (less reflection).
Represent the ice-albedo feedback through the following formula:

children.html: α(T)={αiT≤Tiαo+(αi−αo)(T−To)2(Ti−To)2Ti<T<ToαoT≥To}\alpha(T) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ccc} \alpha_i & & T \le T_i \\ \alpha_o + (\alpha_i-\alpha_o) \frac{(T-T_o)^2}{(T_i-T_o)^2} & & T_i < T < T_o \\ \alpha_o & & T \ge T_o \end{array} \right\}α(T)=⎩⎨⎧​αi​αo​+(αi​−αo​)(Ti​−To​)2(T−To​)2​αo​​​T≤Ti​Ti​<T<To​T≥To​​⎭⎬⎫​
αo=0.289\alpha_o = 0.289αo​=0.289

children.value: is the albedo of a warm, ice-free planet

children.html: αi=0.7\alpha_i = 0.7αi​=0.7

children.value: is the albedo of a very cold, completely ice-covered planet

children.html: To=293T_o = 293To​=293

children.value: K is the threshold temperature above which we assume the planet is ice-free

children.html: Ti=260T_i = 260Ti​=260

children.value: K is the threshold temperature below which we assume the planet is completely ice covered.
For intermediate temperature, this formula gives a smooth variation in albedo with global mean temperature. It is tuned to reproduce the observed albedo

T=288T = 288T=288

statements in Python. Alternatively, you can check out the
) which can make decisions simultaneously on arrays of numbers. There is definitely more than one way to solve this problem. It doesn’t matter how you do it as long as it works!
Now investigate a climate change scenario with this new model:
Suppose that the transmissivity decreases from 0.611 to 0.57 (same as before)
This time the albedo is not a fixed, known number. Instead, it varies with the current value of temperature according the formula you plotted in Part (a).
Unlike when the albedo is a fixed number, it is not possible to solve for the equilibrium temperature analytically. Instead, you will use numerical time-stepping to find the equilibrium temperature
(time-step forward for 50 years from an initial temperature of 288 K and make a graph of the results)
use the function you defined above to compute the albedo for the current temperature
Explain in your own words how the temperature-dependent albedo affects the equilibrium temperature. If the albedo never changed from the observed value
, would the equilibrium temperature be larger or smaller?
Open-ended investigation for extra credit, not required

Something very different occurs in this model if you introduce a strong negative radiative forcing, either by substantially reducing greenhouse gases (which we would represent as an increase in the transmissivity

children.html: τ\tauτ

children.value: ), or by decreasing the incoming solar radiation

children.html: QQQ
